The foundations of quantum theory are a major open problem in mathematics. In this paper we provide a purely categorical approach to the foundations of quantum theory. The approach is based on a set of axioms that are purely categorical and do not presuppose any analytical structure. The axioms are designed to guarantee that the category of Hilbert spaces and bounded linear operators is equivalent to the category of continuous linear operators between categories of probability spaces. The approach provides a framework for the study of the foundations of quantum theory that is independent of any particular mathematical structure.

The Myxozoa are a group of microscopic obligate parasites that cause diseases in a variety of hosts, including humans. Although the evolutionary origin of the Myxozoa has been elusive, a close relationship with cnidarians, a group that includes corals, sea anemones, jellyfish, and hydroids, is supported by some phylogenetic studies and the observation that the distinctive myxozoan structure, the polar capsule, is remarkably similar to the stinging structures (nematocysts) in cnidarians. Here, we present a comparative analysis of the genomes of two distantly related myxozoan species and a cnidarian species, and we show that the myxozoan body plan is the result of extreme genome reduction. Our results suggest that the degeneration of the myxozoan body plan from a free-living cnidarian to a microscopic parasitic cnidarian was accompanied by extreme reduction in genome size and gene content. Our results reveal a mechanism of viral antagonism in which a virus hijacks the Nup98-Rae1 complex to overcome the antiviral action of IFN. The world’s population is expected to reach 10 billion by the middle of the 21st century, and the demand for food is expected to increase by 50% to meet this demand. Earlier studies suggest that crop yields will decline if the optimum growing temperature is exceeded, and that the variability of crop yields will increase. Here, we quantify how the variability of maize yields will change in the world’s major maize-producing and -exporting countries under 2 °C and 4 °C of global warming. Our results show that the probability of simultaneous production losses greater than 10% in any given year increases to 86% under 4 °C warming, and that the instability of global grain trade and international grain prices will increase. These results highlight the urgency of investments in breeding for heat tolerance. They also underscore the importance of food security in the developing world.

The coexistence of many species of large herbivores in the same ecosystem is a fundamental ecological phenomenon. However, despite decades of research, we still do not understand how these species partition resources to avoid competition and achieve coexistence. We show that DNA metabarcoding can be used to quantify diet composition at a species level, and that this approach can reveal that even closely related species of large herbivores partition food resources in ways that are not easily predicted from their body size or digestive physiology. These results suggest that the coexistence of many species of large herbivores may be more linked to plant diversity than previously thought. This may have implications for the management of large herbivore populations in a changing world.

We conducted a large survey of small businesses to understand the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on their operations. We find that many businesses have already laid off workers and closed their doors. However, many businesses are financially fragile, and the majority plan to apply for the CARES Act loans. We also find that the CARES Act loans are not a panacea, and many businesses will struggle to access the funds.

Plastic debris is one of the most common forms of marine pollution. However, the global load of floating plastic on the open ocean is still unknown. We show that the global load of floating plastic on the open ocean is much less than expected, and that the majority of the plastic is concentrated in the convergence zones of the five subtropical gyres. This distribution is mostly due to the size distribution of the floating plastic, which is dominated by small fragments. We propose that the missing plastic is transported to the ocean interior by food webs and ballasting processes, and that it is rapidly lost from the surface of the open ocean.

The global fishing fleet has doubled in size since 1950, and the number of motorized vessels has increased exponentially. The effective catch per unit of effort (CPUE) has decreased, showing the increasing pressure of fisheries on ocean resources. The effective CPUE of most countries in 2015 was a fifth of its 1950s value, which was compared with a global decline in abundance. There are signs, however, of stabilization and more effective management in recent years, with a reduction in fleet sizes in developed countries. Based on historical patterns and allowing for the slowing rate of expansion, 1 million more motorized vessels could join the global fleet by midcentury as developing countries continue to transition away from subsistence fisheries, challenging sustainable use of fisheries' resources.

The ability to reproduce is one of the most important traits in nature. In this study, we show that the ability to provide energy to the mother during pregnancy is a strong determinant of reproductive output. We also show that the type of energy provisioning has a strong effect on the reproductive output of the offspring. This study provides a framework for understanding the evolution of parental care and domestication. It also provides a framework for understanding the evolution of human-animal relationships. This work is important for understanding the evolution of human-animal relationships and the evolution of human-dominated species.

Multiple system atrophy (MSA) is a sporadic neurodegenerative disorder that affects the autonomic nervous system and the basal ganglia. The disease is characterized by the presence of alpha-synuclein (α-syn) aggregates in affected neurons. We report here the results of a proof of concept study in a mouse model of MSA, in which we show that the caspase-1 inhibitor VX-765 is able to reduce the load of α-syn aggregates in the striatum of the mouse model. This effect was associated with a reduction of truncated α-syn, a form of α-syn that is known to be neurotoxic. In addition, VX-765 was able to preserve tyrosine hydroxylase-positive neurons in the substantia nigra of the mouse model. These results suggest that VX-765 could be a promising candidate to achieve disease modification in synucleinopathies by limiting α-syn accumulation. This study provides an important step toward the development of a therapeutic approach for MSA. (PsycINFO Database Record

The endothelium is the lining of the blood vessels and is the most abundant cell type in the body. It is responsible for controlling the exchange of oxygen, nutrients, and waste products between blood and tissue. The endothelium is also responsible for controlling the contractility of the blood vessels, hemostasis, and inflammation. The endothelium is able to control these functions by receiving and integrating information from multiple sources. This paper describes the nature of the communication network that the endothelium uses to integrate this information.

The COVID-19 pandemic has been accompanied by a vast amount of data, much of which is publicly available. However, the data are often difficult to access, and the information they contain is not always easy to interpret. We describe the COVIDcast API, which provides a common interface to a wide range of COVID-19 data, including traditional public health surveillance signals and many auxiliary indicators of COVID-19 activity. The data are available at a fine geographic resolution and are updated daily. We demonstrate that the auxiliary signals in the COVIDcast API are useful for tracking the pandemic and for research and decision-making. The API is a valuable resource for researchers, public health officials, and the general public.

Potassium channels are the most abundant ion channels in the human body. They are involved in a wide variety of physiological processes, such as the control of heart rate and blood pressure, the transmission of nerve impulses, and the regulation of muscle contraction. The selectivity filter is the narrowest part of the channel, where the specific ion is allowed to pass through. The selectivity filter is also the most important site for the allosteric communication between the activation gate and the inactivation gate.

The gut microbiome of herbivores is a complex ecosystem that is influenced by the host and the environment. The role of the gut microbiome in the health of the host is not fully understood, but it is clear that the composition of the microbiome is important for the health of the host. This study shows that anaerobic fungi, which are a component of the gut microbiome, synthesize a variety of natural products that could be used to influence the composition of the microbiome.

Social dominance is a fundamental aspect of social behavior, yet the role of personality traits in the establishment of social hierarchies remains unclear. Here we show that anxiety, a personality trait that predisposes individuals to become subordinate in a social encounter, directly influences social dominance in male outbred rats and identifies an important mediating role for mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens. Our findings highlight a key role for brain energy metabolism in social behavior and point to mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens as a potential marker and avenue of treatment for anxiety-related social disorders. The ability to design and fabricate mechanical devices with desired responses is of great importance for a wide range of applications. However, the use of a single material phase and the design of a specific structure are often limited to the realization of a limited range of responses. Here, we propose a synthesis strategy to design and fabricate structures that can seamlessly and dynamically collaborate to achieve arbitrary and extreme responses. The structures are digitally synthesized through a free-form inverse design approach, and the corresponding responses are physically realized in experiments. The proposed strategy can be extended to design and fabricate structures with complex responses, which can be assembled into architectures to achieve highly complex behaviors. The proposed strategy can be utilized to design and fabricate mechanical devices for a wide range of applications.

Hemoglobin is the oxygen-carrying protein of erythrocytes. The hemoglobin pattern in human blood is determined by the balance between the two fetal hemoglobin (HbF) and adult hemoglobin (HbA) forms. The HbF/HbA ratio is influenced by a number of factors, including the developmental stage of the erythroid cell, the presence of growth factors, and the expression of the HbF-specific mRNA-binding protein IGF2BP1. Here we show that IGF2BP1 expression is developmentally regulated and that IGF2BP1 overexpression in erythroid cells results in a reversal of the adult hemoglobin pattern toward a more fetal-like pattern. These results suggest a mechanism for chronoregulation of fetal and adult hemoglobin expression in humans. This work may have implications for the development of hemoglobin-based oxygen carriers and for the treatment of hemoglobinopathies. (Read more)

Cancer is the number one cause of death worldwide. Despite the tremendous advances in cancer treatment, the survival rate of patients with cancer remains low. One of the main reasons for this is the resistance of cancer cells to the death program induced by oxidative stress. In this study, we found that the activation of the PI3K-AKT-mTOR signaling pathway confers cancer cells with resistance to ferroptosis, a form of regulated necrosis driven by iron-dependent peroxidation of phospholipids. This resistance is mediated by the activation of sterol regulatory element-binding protein 1/stearoyl-CoA desaturase-1-dependent lipogenesis. Furthermore, we demonstrated that the combination of mTORC1 inhibition with ferroptosis induction is effective in preclinical models of cancer. These results suggest that ferroptosis may be a promising therapeutic target for cancer treatment. (Less)

Hypertension is the most common cause of heart failure. The treatment of hypertension is the cornerstone of the treatment of heart failure. The most common drugs for treating hypertension are the L-type Ca2+ channel blockers (LCCBs). However, the use of LCCBs is associated with the development of heart failure. Here, we show that LCCBs promote vascular remodeling through STIM-mediated activation of ORAI. Our data indicate caution against the use of LCCBs in elderly patients or patients with advanced hypertension and/or onset of cardiovascular remodeling, where levels of STIM and ORAI are elevated. This study may help to improve the safety of LCCBs in the treatment of hypertension. (PsycINFO Database Record

The Northwest Forest Plan (NWFP) was a landmark policy that changed the way forests were managed in the Pacific Northwest. We show that the NWFP was not successful in halting the decline of older-forest–associated bird species. In fact, the policy failed to halt the decline of older forests, and the decline of early-seral–associated bird species. We also show that the NWFP was successful in halting clearcutting on federal land, which is a major step toward the conservation of older forests.

Antibiotic resistance is a major threat to global health. Computational approaches are essential tools to this end since their application enables fast and early strategical decisions in the drug development process. Here, we present a rational design approach, in which acylide antibiotics were screened based on computational predictions of solubility, membrane permeability, and binding affinity toward the ribosome. To assess our design strategy, we tested all candidates for in vitro inhibitory activity and then evaluated them in vivo with several antibiotic-resistant strains to determine minimal inhibitory concentrations. The best compounds designed by us show activity, especially when combined with the membrane-weakening drug colistin, against Acinetobacter baumanii, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, and Escherichia coli, which are the three most critical targets from the priority list of pathogens of the World Health Organization. This work is expected to be useful for the development of new antibiotics. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Deep convolutional neural networks have been successfully applied to many image-processing problems in recent works. Popular network architectures often add additional operations and connections to the standard architecture to enable training deeper networks. To achieve accurate results in practice, a large number of trainable parameters are often required. Here, we introduce a network architecture based on using dilated convolutions to capture features at different image scales and densely connecting all feature maps with each other. The resulting architecture is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters and consists of a single set of operations, making it easier to implement, train, and apply in practice, and automatically adapts to different problems. We compare results of the proposed network architecture with popular existing architectures for several segmentation problems, showing that the proposed architecture is able to achieve accurate results with fewer parameters, with a reduced risk of overfitting the training data.

The transport of moisture in the tropics is a critical process for the global energy budget and on geologic timescales, has markedly influenced continental landscapes, migratory pathways, and biological evolution. We present a continuous, first-of-its-kind 1.3-My record of continental hydroclimate and lake-level variability derived from drill core data from Lake Malawi, East Africa. The results show evidence for 24 lake level drops of more than 200 m during the Late Quaternary, including 15 lowstands when water levels were more than 400 m lower than modern. A dramatic shift is observed at the Mid-Pleistocene Transition (MPT), consistent with far-field climate forcing, which separates vastly different hydroclimate regimes before and after 800,000 years ago. The results provide a unique insight into the influence of hydroclimate on the evolution of the Lake Malawi endemic cichlid fish species flock. The use of electronic devices in the hours before bedtime is widespread in the United States and around the world. This study shows that this practice has important consequences for sleep. Participants who read an electronic book on a light-emitting device took longer to fall asleep, had reduced evening sleepiness, and had a later circadian clock than when reading a printed book. These results demonstrate that evening exposure to an electronic device phase-delays the circadian clock, acutely suppresses melatonin, and has important implications for understanding the impact of such technologies on sleep, performance, health, and safety.

The Younger Dryas boundary (YDB) is a key event in the Earth’s history, and one or more bolide impacts are hypothesized to have triggered the YDB. In support of this hypothesis, varying peak abundances of magnetic grains with iridium and magnetic microspherules have been reported at the YDB. We show that the Osmium isotope composition of the YDB is consistent with the Os in bulk samples and magnetic grains/microspherules being derived from the Earth. In contrast, the Os in the YDB site in Pennsylvania is likely derived from a source in the Grenville Province of northeastern North America.

CTLA-4 is a well-known negative regulator of T cell activation, but its role in the development of autoimmunity and in the regulation of T cell responses is still debated. Here, we show that CTLA-4 is essential for the development of autoimmunity in adult mice, but not in congenital deficiency. Moreover, we show that CTLA-4 is essential for the development of autoimmunity in both the central and the peripheral immune system.

Beetles are arguably the most speciose group of animals, but the origin and diversification of beetles remain poorly understood. We used a comprehensive dataset of 154 beetle genomes and transcriptomes to trace the evolution of genes enabling symbiont-independent digestion of plant cell walls, which is a key trait of beetles. Our results show that the origin of beetles coincided with the evolution of genes encoding enzymes that digest plant cell walls, and that this led to the diversification of beetles. This suggests that the evolution of beetles was driven by multiple factors, including low extinction rates over a long evolutionary history, the codiversification of beetles and angiosperms, and the adaptive radiations of specialized herbivorous beetles following convergent horizontal transfers of microbial genes encoding plant cell wall-degrading enzymes. This study provides insights into the evolution of beetles, which are arguably the most diverse group of animals. (Abridged)

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our algorithm can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The extent to which larger populations enhance cumulative cultural evolution (CCE) is a topic of intense debate. We report a large-scale experiment (n = 543) that investigates the CCE of technology (paper planes and their flight distances) using a transmission-chain design. Population size was manipulated such that participants could learn from the paper planes constructed by one, two, or four models from the prior generation. These social-learning conditions were compared with an asocial individual-learning condition in which individual participants made repeated attempts at constructing a paper plane, without having access to any planes produced by other participants. Larger populations generated greater variation in plane performance and gave participants access to better-adapted planes, but this did not enhance CCE. In fact, there was an inverse relationship between population size and CCE: plane flight distance did not improve over the experimental generations in the 2-Model and 4-Model conditions, but did improve over generations in the 1-Model social-learning condition. The incremental improvement in plane flight distance in the 1-Model social-learning condition was comparable to that in the Individual Learning condition, highlighting the importance of trial-and-error learning

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia and the fifth leading cause of death in the United States. The strongest genetic risk factor influencing susceptibility to AD is apolipoprotein E (APOE) genotype. APOE has three common isoforms in humans, E2, E3, and E4. The presence of two copies of the E4 allele increases risk by ∼12-fold whereas E2 allele is associated with an ∼twofold decreased risk for AD. These data put APOE central to AD pathophysiology, but it is not yet clear how APOE alleles modify AD risk. Here, we report a novel role for APOE in controlling the phagocytic capacity of astrocytes that is highly dependent on APOE isoform. They also suggest the hypothesis that AD susceptibility of APOE4 may originate in part from defective phagocytic capacity of astrocytes which accelerates the rate of accumulation of senescent synapses, enhancing synaptic vulnerability to classical-complement-cascade mediated neurodegeneration.

The Earth's inner core is a solid core that is separated from the mantle by a sharp boundary. It is one of the most mysterious parts of the Earth, and its formation is still a mystery. The formation of the inner core is a crystallization process, which starts with the nucleation of the first crystal. However, the nucleation mechanism of the inner core is still unknown. This study shows that the nucleation of the body-centered cubic phase of iron is much easier than that of the hcp phase, which is the most stable phase of iron. This mechanism reduces the required undercooling of iron nucleation, which provides a key factor in solving the inner core nucleation paradox.

Marijuana is the most commonly used illicit drug in the United States. Although the effects of chronic marijuana use on the brain are well known, the effects of acute marijuana use on the brain are less understood. Here, we show that the brain’s reactivity to methylphenidate, a drug that elevates extracellular dopamine (DA), is reduced in marijuana abusers, who also show increased negative emotionality and addictive behaviors. These findings suggest that the brain’s reactivity to DA stimulation might contribute to the negative emotionality and addictive behaviors associated with marijuana use.

Language is the most complex form of communication, and its processing is thought to be supported by a specialized network of brain regions. However, the mechanisms of this network remain poorly understood. Here, we show that artificial neural networks trained on large datasets of natural language predict neural responses in the human brain to sentences. These models are not only accurate predictors of the brain’s responses, but also of the speed with which the brain responds. These results provide computational evidence that the speed–accuracy tradeoff is fundamental to the mechanisms of language processing in the brain.

Deep learning (DL) has been a major advance in machine learning, but it has been criticized for its instability. This paper shows that the instability of DL is not a general property of machine learning, but rather a property of DL. We prove that there are problems in machine learning where one can prove the existence of stable neural networks (NNs), but there is no algorithm that can train such a NN. This result implies a classification theory of conditions under which one can compute stable NNs with a given accuracy by an algorithm. We introduce a fast iterative restarted network (FIRENET) that we prove is stable and numerically verify is fast and stable. Moreover, we prove that only O(|log (ϵ)|) layers are needed for an ϵ-accurate solution to the inverse problem.

The COVID-19 pandemic is a global tragedy. The scientific community has been working hard to understand the virus and its spread. One of the most influential studies in this field is a classic experiment published in 1972. It is often cited as evidence that people are unable to understand exponential growth. However, its design flaws were not noticed at the time, and the study has become a canonical example of a flawed experiment. Here, we discuss the flaws of the study and its implications for the field.

Leprosy is a disease that has been with us for thousands of years. It is caused by two species of bacteria, Mycobacterium leprae and Mycobacterium lepromatosis, which have diverged from a common ancestor approximately 14 million years ago. This study shows that the two species have retained many of the same functions, and that the loss of some functions has occurred in one of the species. This study also shows that the two species are still able to cause similar diseases in humans. This suggests that the two species are still able to adapt to the human host, and that the diseases they cause are still relevant to human health. (Abridged)

The study of the evolution of entanglement and entropy is a central topic in the field of quantum many-body physics. It is of fundamental interest, as it is a key concept in the foundations of quantum mechanics, and it is also of practical relevance, as it is a necessary ingredient for the design of quantum technologies. However, a complete understanding of the evolution of entanglement and entropy is still lacking for interacting systems, which are the most relevant ones from a practical point of view. Here, we provide a complete understanding of the entanglement dynamics in the space–time scaling limit for the paradigmatic case of the Heisenberg chain.

The COVID-19 pandemic has been devastating, and the search for a vaccine is ongoing. Here, we describe a vaccine candidate that is highly attenuated, easy to manufacture, and has the potential to be used in mass vaccination programs.

The Second Pandemic of plague (14–19th centuries) led to high mortality and recurrent epidemics for hundreds of years. The vector of the disease is still debated, with the most common hypothesis being that rats were the main transmission pathway. However, this study shows that human ectoparasites, such as fleas or lice, could have been the primary vectors of the disease. This would have important implications for the control of the disease, as it would have been easier to control the spread of the disease by humans than by rats.

The evolution of brain size is a major topic of debate in the field of comparative neurobiology. However, the evolution of brain numbers, which is more appropriate for understanding the evolution of cognitive capacity, has received little attention. This study provides a comprehensive analysis of the evolution of brain numbers in amniotes, which is the most inclusive group of chordates that includes birds and mammals. We show that reptiles have not only small brains relative to body size but also low neuronal densities, resulting in average neuron numbers over 20 times lower than those in birds and mammals of similar body size. This has important implications for studies using relative brain size as a proxy when looking for evolutionary drivers of animal cognition.

TRAP1 (TNF receptor-associated protein) is a mitochondrial molecular chaperone that is broadly considered to be an anticancer target. However, the function of TRAP1 in mitochondria of normal cells is not well understood. We have used TRAP1-null cells and transient TRAP1 silencing/overexpression to show that TRAP1 regulates a metabolic switch between oxidative phosphorylation and aerobic glycolysis in immortalized mouse fibroblasts and in human tumor cells. TRAP1-deficiency promotes an increase in mitochondrial respiration and fatty acid oxidation, and in cellular accumulation of tricarboxylic acid cycle intermediates, ATP and reactive oxygen species. At the same time, glucose metabolism is suppressed. TRAP1 may act as a tumor suppressor in some settings. This study also provides a mechanistic basis for the observation that TRAP1 expression is inversely correlated with tumor grade in several cancers. These data suggest that TRAP1 may be a promising target for cancer therapy. (Abridged)

Actin depolymerizing factor (ADF) is a protein that is involved in severing actin filaments. However, the mechanism by which it does so is not known. Here, we show that the action of ADF is strongly influenced by the mechanical properties of the actin filament network in which it acts. We show that the mechanical properties of the network can be tuned by the geometry of the network, the presence of cross-links, and the presence of motors. We propose that these mechanical properties are important for the action of ADF in cells.

Fructose, a common sweetener found in many beverages and foods, is often promoted as a healthier alternative to glucose, a common sweetener found in many other foods and beverages. However, the relative appetite-suppressing effects of fructose versus glucose have been unclear. In this study, we show that ingestion of fructose relative to glucose results in greater activation of brain regions involved in attention and reward processing and may promote feeding behavior. These findings have implications for understanding the mechanisms of action of common sweeteners and may have clinical relevance for the treatment of obesity. (PsycINFO Database Record

Madagascar is a unique island in terms of its biodiversity and its cultural diversity. However, the settlement history of Madagascar is still debated. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across Madagascar, and we found that the Malagasy population is a mixture of Bantu and Austronesian populations, with a limited contribution from Europe and the Middle East. We also found that the settlement of Madagascar happened in a sex-biased and geographically heterogeneous way, suggesting that the settlement of Madagascar was the result of multiple independent colonization events. Finally, we found that a few centuries are sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. This study provides a better understanding of the settlement history of Madagascar and will help to improve the conservation of the biodiversity of the island. This article is protected by copyright. We show that people’s emotions are influenced by the emotions of others on Facebook. This is a form of emotional contagion, which has been observed in laboratory experiments but is controversial in the real world. We show that the influence of others’ emotions is not limited to in-person interaction, and that the influence of others’ positive experiences is positive for people. These results suggest that the observation of others’ positive experiences constitutes a positive experience for people. They also suggest that the observation of others’ negative experiences constitutes a negative experience for people. This work has implications for the design of social media platforms and for our understanding of the influence of others on our emotions. It also suggests that the observation of others’ positive experiences constitutes a positive experience for people.

The ribosome is a complex machine that translates messenger RNA (mRNA) into a protein. The mRNA sequence is a critical component of this process, and many modifications can alter the structure and function of the mRNA. In this study, we show that the presence of a single modification, pseudouridine (Ψ), in the mRNA sequence can alter the rate of translation. We also show that the presence of Ψ in the mRNA sequence can lead to the synthesis of multiple peptide products from a single mRNA sequence. These findings suggest that the presence of Ψ in the mRNA sequence can have subtle effects on the translation process. This work provides insight into the role of mRNA modifications in the translation process. (Abridged)

This study shows that the feeling that one’s life is filled with worthwhile activities is associated with a wide range of positive outcomes, including better health, social relationships, and life satisfaction. This finding has implications for public health, as it suggests that promoting a sense of worthwhile living may be an effective way to improve the health and well-being of older people.

The evolution of larger body size is a defining feature of the evolution of mammals. This study shows that the evolution of an aquatic lifestyle is driving three of the four extant aquatic mammal clades toward a size attractor at ∼500 kg. The existence of this body size attractor and the relatively rapid selection toward, and limited deviation from, this attractor rule out most hypothesized drivers of size increase. These three independent body size increases and a shared aquatic optimum size are consistent with control by differences in the scaling of energetic intake and cost functions with body size between the terrestrial and aquatic realms.

Rhinovirus is the most common cause of the common cold. The virus replicates more efficiently at the cool temperatures found in the nasal cavity than at core body temperature. We show that the temperature-dependent growth phenotype of rhinovirus is dependent on the innate immune system.

Bacteria are constantly exposed to a variety of environmental signals, and have evolved a wide range of sensing systems to appropriately respond to these signals. Here we demonstrate that the opportunistic pathogen Pseudomonas aeruginosa detects contact with surfaces on short timescales using the mechanical activity of its type IV pili, a major surface adhesin. This signal transduction mechanism requires attachment of type IV pili to a solid surface, followed by pilus retraction and signal transduction through the Chp chemosensory system, a chemotaxis-like sensory system that regulates cAMP production and transcription of hundreds of genes, including key virulence factors. The use of pesticides in agriculture has increased dramatically in recent decades, and the number of pesticides is constantly increasing. This study provides a comprehensive analysis of the global pesticide situation, which is of great importance for the protection of surface water. We show that the use of pesticides in agriculture is widespread and that the concentrations of these chemicals in surface water are high. This has a negative impact on the biodiversity of aquatic organisms.

The COVID-19 pandemic has had a profound impact on human society, and the virus has spread to many animal species, including deer. We report the detection of SARS-CoV-2 in deer, which has important implications for the long-term persistence of the pandemic. Our findings highlight the need for a proactive “One Health” approach to obtain enhanced understanding of the ecology, molecular evolution, and dissemination of SARS-CoV-2. This approach will be critical to prevent the emergence of new variants that are better adapted to animal reservoirs and humans. Our study also provides a model for the rapid and effective response to the emergence of new infectious diseases in wildlife. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The proliferation of large dams in the developing world is a major concern for the environment, people, and the climate. This paper examines the causes of the problem, the consequences of building dams, and the solutions that are needed.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia, and the lack of effective treatments has led to a growing need for a better understanding of the disease process. Here we report the identification of an Aβ-burdened neuron as a major source of inflammation in the brain, which may be a key contributor to the development of AD.

The domestication of the chicken (Gallus gallus) is one of the most important events in human history. The earliest evidence for the domestication of the chicken comes from the archaeological record of the Near East, where the species was first domesticated. The earliest evidence for the economic exploitation of the chicken comes from the archaeological record of the Southern Levant, where the species was first domesticated. We show that the earliest evidence for the economic exploitation of the chicken in the Southern Levant is at least 100 y older than the earliest evidence from the Near East.

The folding of a protein is a complex process that is not yet understood. This study shows that the folding of a large protein, maltose binding protein, proceeds through distinct steps, each of which is associated with a distinct folding intermediate. The results suggest that the folding of a protein is a multistep process, each of which is associated with a distinct folding intermediate.

The accumulation of dinucleoside tetraphosphates (Np4) in response to stress has been linked to the formation of RNA caps, but the cellular functions of these molecules have remained elusive. Here, we show that, in Escherichia coli cells experiencing disulfide stress, the RNA pyrophosphohydrolase RppH, which is known to remove Np4 caps, also removes dinucleoside triphosphates (TTPs) and diphosphates (DPP) from the 5′ ends of transcripts. This activity is required for the rapid degradation of Np4-capped RNAs, which are otherwise protected from decay. The unique manner in which Np4-capped 5′ ends bind to the active site of RppH positions the δ-phosphate, rather than the β-phosphate, for hydrolytic attack, generating triphosphorylated RNA as the primary product of decapping. This deprotection mechanism is required to produce the monophosphorylated 5′ terminus needed to stimulate rapid RNA degradation. Our findings have implications for the regulation of gene expression during disulfide stress. (Abridged)

Sepsis is a life-threatening condition that is associated with a high rate of mortality. Although there are several therapeutic strategies to reduce the severity of sepsis, there is no specific treatment to restore immune function. Here, we show that arginine, a key amino acid in the urea cycle, is a promising candidate to improve the immune response in sepsis. We demonstrate that arginine administration increases arginine plasma levels and restores T cell mitochondrial function and proliferation while reducing the expansion of Treg and MDSCs. These results suggest that arginine could be a promising therapeutic strategy to improve the immune response in sepsis. This study provides evidence for developing citrulline-based clinical studies in sepsis. (PsycINFO Database Record

The biomass of the biosphere is a key parameter for understanding the structure and dynamics of the biosphere. However, a global, quantitative view of how the biomass of different taxa compare with one another is still lacking. Here, we assemble the overall biomass composition of the biosphere, establishing a census of the ≈550 Gt C of biomass distributed among all of the kingdoms of life. We show that the biomass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined, and that the global marine biomass pyramid contains more consumers than producers, thus increasing the scope of previous observations on inverse food pyramids. Finally, we highlight that the mass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined and report the historical impact of humanity on the global biomass of prominent taxa, including mammals, fish, and plants. Our results provide a global view of the biomass of the biosphere and its distribution among the kingdoms of life. They are a key input for understanding the structure and dynamics of the biosphere.

Self-organized criticality (SOC) is a phenomenon in which a dynamical system evolves at a constant rate, without being externally driven, and in which the system’s rate of change is insensitive to its current state. SOC is observed in a variety of natural and man-made systems, including earthquakes, sandpiles, fire spreading, neural networks, and financial markets. In this paper, we report on our discovery of a continuous model of SOC. Our model is a certain scaling limit of the sandpile model, the first and archetypical model of SOC. We discuss the dichotomy between continuous and discrete models in several contexts. Our aim in this paper is to present an idealized tropical toy model, requiring further investigation.

Diamond is a unique material with a wide range of applications in electronics, photonics, and quantum technologies. It is a promising material for the next generation of devices, but its properties can be modified to improve their performance. In this work, we show that diamond can be transformed into a metal, and back to a semiconductor, by applying small amounts of strain. This opens up new possibilities for the design of diamond-based devices with tailored properties. Our work provides a fundamental understanding of the properties of diamond under strain and has implications for the development of new technologies based on this material.

The study of the structure and function of peptides is of great interest to the scientific community. This study focuses on the antifungal activity of a unique structure, which is highly conserved in the legume nodule-specific cysteine-rich (NCR) peptide family. The antifungal activity of the peptide was demonstrated in vitro and in planta. The mode of action of the peptide was also elucidated. This work provides a structural basis for the antifungal activity of the NCR peptide and paves the way for future development of this class of peptides as a spray-on fungistat/fungicide. The male–female reproductive axis is a model system for understanding the molecular mechanisms of intersexual continuity. However, the extent of molecular continuity between males and females is largely unknown. We used proteomics and isotopic labeling to characterize the posttesticular life history of the Drosophila sperm proteome and determine the extent of molecular continuity between males and females. We show that the male–female axis is characterized by a dynamic process of protein association and dissociation. We also show that female-derived proteins are associated with sperm immediately after mating and comprise nearly 20% of the postmating sperm proteome. Our research provides a comprehensive characterization of sperm proteome dynamics and expands our understanding of the critical process of sperm–FRT interactions. (Abridged)

Von Willebrand factor (VWF) is a large protein that is essential for the adhesion of platelets to the vessel wall. Mutations in VWF cause the common bleeding disorder, von Willebrand disease (VWD). We show that the A1 domain in VWF is able to switch between two states, one of which is more effective at binding platelets. This mechanism provides a mechanism for the effects of mutations in VWF, explaining the pathophysiology of VWD. The mechanism is also likely to be important in other diseases in which VWF is involved. The mechanism is also likely to be important in other diseases in which VWF is involved.

The human microbiome is a complex ecosystem of bacteria that has been studied for decades. However, the viral component of the microbiome has been more difficult to study, and the lack of a comprehensive database has hindered the ability to understand the role of viruses in human health. This study is a major step forward in the field, as it provides a database of over 45,000 unique human-associated viruses, with a high level of completeness. The study also provides a resource for the community to continue to discover and study the role of viruses in human health.

Aerosol–cloud interaction (ACI) is one of the most important processes in the climate system. However, the complexity of ACI makes it difficult to be well represented in current climate models. The main reason is that the observational capability is inadequate. To overcome this conundrum, we introduce the dual-field-of-view (FOV) high-spectral-resolution lidar (HSRL) for simultaneously profiling aerosol and water cloud properties, especially water cloud microphysical properties. This instrument, verified by the Monte Carlo simulation and coincident observations of other techniques, was used to conduct a case study over Beijing. The observations show that the increased aerosol loading led to increased droplet number concentration and decreased droplet effective radius, which is consistent with expectations. However, the aerosol-induced cloud water increase caused by suppressed rain formation can be canceled out by enhanced evaporation. Thus, these observations constitute substantial and significant additions to understanding ACI. This technique is expected to represent a significant step forward in characterizing ACI. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The temperature of Earth’s surface has been a subject of debate for many years. The temperature of the surface of the Earth is important for understanding the evolution of life on the planet. This study provides a new perspective on the temperature of the Earth’s surface in the past.

Ion channels are the main regulators of ion flow and are important for the normal function of the nervous system and the cardiovascular system. Ion channels are also involved in a variety of diseases, such as epilepsy, cardiac arrhythmia, and hypertension. The study of ion channels is important for the development of new drugs and for the understanding of the normal and abnormal functions of the nervous and cardiovascular systems.

Malaria is one of the most devastating diseases in the world, with an estimated 207 million cases and 445,000 deaths in 2015. The parasite, Plasmodium, uses a variety of mechanisms to invade the red blood cell (RBC) and cause disease. Here, we show that the parasite erythrocyte-binding antigen 175 (EBA175) alters the biophysical properties of the RBC, reducing the energy barrier to invasion. This is a major change in our understanding of malaria invasion, suggesting that it is a balance between parasite and host cell physical forces working together to facilitate entry. This work provides a new perspective on the invasion process and could lead to the development of new strategies for malaria control. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Diamond is a unique material with a wide range of applications in electronics, photonics, and quantum technologies. It is a promising material for the next generation of devices, but its properties can be modified to improve their performance. In this work, we show that diamond can be transformed into a metal, and back to a semiconductor, by applying small amounts of strain. This opens up new possibilities for the design of diamond-based devices with tailored properties. Our work provides a fundamental understanding of the properties of diamond under strain and has implications for the design of diamond-based devices in the future.

Influenza virus is a major cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. In the temperate regions, seasonal outbreaks of influenza correlate with decreases in ambient humidity. While low humidity is known to enhance viral transmission, its impact on host response to influenza virus infection and disease outcome remains unclear. Here, we show that housing mice in low relative humidity makes them more susceptible to severe disease following respiratory challenge with influenza A virus. We find that exposure to dry air impairs host defense against influenza infection, reduces tissue repair, and inflicts caspase-dependent disease pathology. These results indicate that exposure to dry air impairs host defense against influenza infection, reduces tissue repair, and inflicts caspase-dependent disease pathology. Our findings have implications for the development of strategies to mitigate the impact of influenza on human health. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The brain is thought to build a tree-like structure of the sentence as a whole, from the top down, by merging words into phrases. However, whether and how the brain builds such structures is unknown. Here, we show that the brain’s activity increases with each successive word in a sentence, but suddenly increases whenever words can be merged into a phrase. This suggests that the brain applies a merge operation to the incoming language stream, which is consistent with a neural implementation of a bottom-up or left-corner parser. Our results provide initial intracranial evidence for the neurophysiological reality of the merge operation postulated by linguists and suggest that the brain compresses syntactically well-formed sequences of words into a hierarchy of nested phrases. This may be a fundamental property of the brain’s language processing system.

Axin is a key component of the Wnt pathway, which is involved in many important biological processes. In this study, we show that the two forms of Axin in vertebrates are not only similar at the protein level but also genetically redundant. We also show that the two forms of Axin are differentially regulated on the transcriptional and proteostatic level, which confers differential responsiveness that can be used in tissue-specific regulation. Such subtle features may distinguish other redundant gene pairs that are commonly found in vertebrates through gene knockout experiments. This study provides a deeper understanding of the mechanism of redundant genes and may help in the development of new strategies for gene therapy.

Obesity is a major health problem in the United States and worldwide. The causes of obesity are complex, but one of the most important factors is the ability to overeat. Here we report on a brain circuit that may contribute to this phenomenon. We show that electrical stimulation of the lateral hypothalamus, a brain region that is important in the regulation of feeding, causes rapid and vigorous eating in sated animals. We also show that this circuit is dependent on dopamine neurons in the ventral tegmental area and dopamine neurons in the brainstem, but not on dopamine neurons in the nucleus accumbens, a brain region that is important in the reward aspects of eating. Thus, we present a characterization of a brain circuit that may promote overeating and contribute to obesity. This work may help to identify new targets for the development of therapeutic strategies for obesity. (PsycINFO Database Record

Nitrogen is the most important nutrient for plant growth, and the availability of nitrogen in the soil is the main limiting factor for crop production. The use of nitrogen-fixing bacteria in agriculture is a promising strategy to increase the efficiency of nitrogen use and to reduce the use of chemical fertilizers. However, the use of nitrogen-fixing bacteria in agriculture is limited by the fact that the bacteria are not able to fix nitrogen when they are not in contact with the host plant. Here, we report the development of a synthetic plant-controlled symbiosis in which the nitrogen-fixing bacteria are only able to fix nitrogen when in contact with the desired host plant. This work represents a key milestone toward the development of a synthetic plant-controlled symbiosis in which the bacteria fix nitrogen only when in contact with the desired host plant and are prevented from interaction with nontarget plant species. This work is expected to have a significant impact on the field of synthetic biology and on the development of sustainable agriculture. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

We study the effectiveness of a community-based monitoring program in the Peruvian Amazon. The program was randomly assigned to 39 of 76 communities. The results from our analysis suggest that the program reduced tree cover loss, but the estimated effects from the experiment are imprecise. Data from monitoring records and community surveys provide evidence about how the program may affect forest outcomes. Community members perceived that the program’s monitors were new authorities with influence over forest management and that the monitors’ incentivized patrols were substitutes for traditional, unincentivized citizen patrols that suffer from free riding and inhibit timely community detection of and responses to deforestation. Should our findings be replicated elsewhere, they imply that externally facilitated community-based monitoring protocols that combine remote-sensed early deforestation alerts with training and incentives for monitors could contribute to sustainable forest management.

Hearing is a fundamental sense of many animals, including all mammals, birds, some reptiles, amphibians, fish, and arthropods. The auditory organs of these animals are extremely diverse in anatomy after hundreds of millions of years of evolution, yet they are all made up of cellular tissue and are morphologically part of the bodies of animals. Here, we show that hearing in the orb-weaving spider Larinioides sclopetarius is not constrained by the organism’s body but is extended through outsourcing hearing to its extended phenotype, the proteinaceous, self-manufactured orb web.

We show that a rapid phaseout of fossil-fuel-related emissions and major reductions of other anthropogenic sources are needed to save millions of lives, restore aerosol-perturbed rainfall patterns, and limit global warming to 2 °C. We also show that aerosols mask the anthropogenic rise in global temperature, and that removing pollution particles liberates 0.51(±0.03) °C and all pollution particles 0.73(±0.03) °C warming, reaching around 2 °C over North America and Northeast Asia.

The COVID-19 pandemic continues to have a devastating impact on global health and the economy. The development of vaccines is a major success, but the cost of these vaccines may limit their global access. We report a strategy to improve the manufacturability of a subunit vaccine candidate for COVID-19, which could be used to develop vaccines for other diseases.

The study of the role of ALK in human cancer has led to the identification of a number of ALKAL proteins as ligands. Here, we show that zebrafish ALKALs are able to activate ALK/LTK family receptors in vivo. Our results provide evidence for the involvement of ALK/LTK family receptors in neural crest development and suggest that ALKALs are potential therapeutic targets in neuroblastoma.

The emergence of plague as a devastating disease in human history is a well-documented event, but the details of its early evolution are still largely unknown. We present 17 Yersinia pestis genomes from the Late Neolithic to the Bronze Age in Eurasia, which provide a more complete picture of the evolution of plague during this critical period. Our results suggest that the emergence of plague as a human pathogen was a gradual process, with a single lineage persisting over millennia without significant diversification. We also discover the presence of the flea-adapted form of plague in Bronze Age Iberia, suggesting a much wider geographic spread of this form of plague than previously thought. These data provide insights into the early evolution and ecology of plague, which will be useful for understanding the origins of this disease and its impact on human history. (Less)

This work examined whether the endorsement of the culturally idealized form of masculinity—hegemonic masculinity (HM)—accounted for unique variance in men’s and women’s support for Donald Trump across seven studies (n = 2,007). Consistent with our theoretical backdrop, in the days (Studies 1 and 2) and months (Studies 3 through 6) following the 2016 American presidential election, women’s and men’s endorsement of HM predicted voting for and evaluations of Trump, over and above political party affiliation, gender, race, and education. These effects held when controlling for respondents’ trust in the government, in contrast to a populist explanation of support for Trump. In addition, as conceptualized, HM was associated with less trust in the government (Study 3), more sexism (Study 4), more racism (Study 5), and more xenophobia (Study 6) but continued to predict unique variance in evaluations of Trump when controlling for each of these factors. The agricultural use of grasslands has been shown to be a major driver of the global C cycle. However, the effects of different management practices on soil C storage and the distribution of this C between particulate and mineral-associated pools are highly uncertain. We show that the use of diverse, rotationally grazed pastures can increase soil C storage and the distribution of this C between particulate and mineral-associated pools. These results highlight the potential of well-managed grasslands to sequester and store C in the soil, which is critical for climate-smart agriculture. This study also provides a global synthesis of the effects of soil health management practices on soil C storage and distribution in annual cropping systems. This synthesis highlights the need for more research on the effects of soil health management practices on soil C storage and distribution in annual cropping systems worldwide. (Abridged)

The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the need for a better understanding of the risk of spillover of zoonotic viruses to humans and the development of strategies to mitigate that risk. We present a framework for identifying and prioritizing wildlife viruses with the greatest potential to spill over and spread to cause epidemics and pandemics. We also present a web tool, SpillOver, that allows users to explore the results and to prioritize research and public health interventions. SpillOver is a living, interactive database that can be refined over time to continue to improve the quality and public availability of information on viral threats to human health. We hope that SpillOver will be used by policy makers and health scientists to inform research and public health interventions for prevention and rapid control of disease outbreaks.

Nectar is a reward that plants offer to pollinators for pollination. The color of nectar is an important trait that attracts pollinators, but the mechanisms underlying the production of colorful nectar are poorly understood. We show that the red color of the nectar of the plant Nesocodon mauritianus is derived from a previously undescribed alkaloid, nesocodin. We also identify nesocodin in the red nectar of the hummingbird-visited Jaltomata herrerae and provide molecular evidence for convergent evolution of this trait. This work identifies a convergently evolved trait in two vertebrate-pollinated species, suggesting that the red pigment is selectively favored and that only a limited number of compounds are likely to underlie this type of adaptation. This work also provides a model for the evolution of colorful nectar in plants. (Abridged)

We present a study of the genetic history of the population of southern Germany during the Early Middle Ages. We show that the genetic ancestry of men is mostly of northern and central European origin, but that women exhibit a very high genetic heterogeneity, including signals of genetic ancestry ranging from western Europe to East Asia. In addition, we found that many alleles associated with recent positive selection were already at modern-like frequencies in European populations ∼1,500 years ago.

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a severe human pathogen that causes ∼36% fatality in infected patients. Believed to have originated from bats, MERS-CoV is genetically related to bat coronaviruses HKU4 and HKU5. To understand how bat coronaviruses transmit to humans, we investigated the receptor usage and cell entry activity of the virus-surface spike proteins of HKU4 and HKU5. We found that dipeptidyl peptidase 4 (DPP4), the receptor for MERS-CoV, is also the receptor for HKU4, but not HKU5. Despite sharing a common receptor, MERS-CoV and HKU4 spikes demonstrated functional differences. These results establish DPP4 as a functional receptor for HKU4 and host cellular proteases as a host range determinant for HKU4. They also suggest that DPP4-recognizing bat coronaviruses threaten human health because of their spikes’ capability to adapt to human cells for cross-species transmissions. We describe the use of a global cloud-based metagenomic sequencing platform to investigate the pathogen landscape of undifferentiated febrile illness in a resource-scarce setting. We demonstrate that mNGS can be used to identify a variety of vector-borne, zoonotic, and emerging pathogens, including the first detection of chikungunya virus in Cambodia. This approach can be used to identify the breadth of endemic, zoonotic, or emerging pathogens and deployment of rapid public health response. This work is a step toward the development of a global cloud-based pathogen surveillance platform that can be used in resource-scarce settings to better understand the pathogen landscape and mitigate the spread of infectious diseases. This work is important for the global community in the context of the COVID-19 pandemic.

The human genome is replicated in a process that is similar to that of S. cerevisiae, but there are some important differences. One of the most significant is the stability of the DNA polymerase δ (pol δ) holoenzyme. In S. cerevisiae, the stability of the pol δ holoenzyme is so high that it is thought to be the primary reason for the fidelity of replication. In humans, the stability of the pol δ holoenzyme is much lower, and it is thought that this is due to the lack of a recycling mechanism. We show that the stability of the pol δ holoenzyme in humans is not due to a lack of recycling, but rather due to a loose association with the PCNA sliding clamp.

The origin of life is one of the most important and enduring questions in biology. In the hypothesized RNA world, before the evolution of proteins, genetic information was stored in RNA molecules that were replicated by ribozymes. In this paper, we describe the first in vitro RNA world. We use in vitro selection to improve the activity of a ribozyme that can synthesize RNA from an RNA template. The improved ribozyme can replicate RNA, amplify RNA templates, and synthesize a variety of functional RNA molecules. This work provides a foundation for the study of the origin of life in the laboratory. It also provides a powerful tool for the study of RNA biology in general.

We use computer vision methods to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We find that the physical appearances of neighborhoods are correlated with the economic and demographic characteristics of their residents. These results are consistent with three classical theories of urban change: the “human capital” theory, the “tipping” theory, and the “invasion” theory. Our results suggest that the physical appearances of neighborhoods are important to the economic and social well-being of their residents. They also suggest that the physical appearances of neighborhoods can be used to understand the dynamics of urban change.

The pathogenesis of COVID-19 is still unclear. In this study, we found that tocilizumab, which targets the IL-6 pathways, can improve the clinical outcomes of severe and critical patients with COVID-19 immediately.

Copper is an essential micronutrient, but also a toxic metal that can cause oxidative damage. The ability of fungi to regulate copper homeostasis is well established, but the existence of copper-binding natural products in fungi is less well known. Here we report the existence of a copper-binding isocyanide biosynthetic gene cluster in Aspergillus fumigatus, which has significant antimicrobial properties and may be involved in the regulation of copper homeostasis.

The formation of tridymite, a low-pressure, high-temperature (>870 °C) polymorph of silica, is a unique feature of the Lake Gale catchment environment on Mars. The presence of tridymite, cristobalite, feldspar, and any residual high-SiO2 glass in a “Lake Gale” catchment environment suggests that the sediment source for these materials is the Gale crater wall/rim/central peak. Opaline silica could form during diagenesis from high-SiO2 glass, as amorphous precipitated silica, or as a residue of acidic leaching in the sediment source region or at Marias Pass. The amorphous mixed-cation salts and oxides and possibly the crystalline magnetite (otherwise detrital) are primary precipitates and/or their diagenesis products derived from multiple aqueous solutions having variable compositions, temperatures, and acidities.

Frost damage is a major threat to the productivity of plants and animals across the world’s temperate and boreal zones. We show that the geographic distribution of frost damage is changing in response to climate warming, and that this change is already affecting the performance of forests. Our findings can inform decision-making in land management, forestry, agriculture, and insurance policy.

Th17 cells are a major component of the inflammatory response in certain types of inflammatory bowel disease. However, Th17 cells can be divided into two major subsets, one of which retains an IL-17A+ phenotype, whereas the other, “Th1-like,” expresses IFN-γ. It is unclear what role these subsets play in inflammatory bowel disease. Here, we show that Th17 cells can provide “help” for the development of classic Th1 cells and that the development of colitis requires the transition of a subset of Th17 precursors to Th1-like cells. These results indicate that Th17 cells are potent mediators of colitis pathogenesis by dual mechanisms: by directly transitioning to Th1-like cells and by supporting the development of classic Th1 cells. This plasticity may be important in the development of inflammatory bowel disease. (PsycINFO Database Record

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a fatal neurodegenerative disease with no cure. The disease is caused by degeneration of motor neurons, leading to paralysis and death. The disease is heterogeneous, with different causes and different stages of disease at death. We report a method to rapidly produce motor neuron-like cells from living patients with ALS, enabling disease modeling and high-throughput drug screening. This method will enable the study of the disease in the living, and the development of therapies to alleviate motor neuron toxicity. This will help to improve the quality of life of ALS patients and provide a better understanding of the disease. This method will also enable the study of the disease in the living, and the development of therapies to alleviate motor neuron toxicity. This will help to improve the quality of life of ALS patients and provide a better understanding of the disease. (Less)

The role of the microbiome in the transmission of infectious diseases is a rapidly developing field. Here, we show that a human pathogen, Anaplasma phagocytophilum, modifies the microbiome of its vector, the blacklegged tick, Ixodes scapularis, to more efficiently colonize the tick. We demonstrate that A. phagocytophilum induces the tick to express antifreeze glycoprotein, which alters the gut microbiota and the integrity of the peritrophic matrix, which is a critical obstacle for Anaplasma colonization. These findings provide insights into the mechanisms by which a human pathogen appropriates an arthropod antibacterial protein to alter the gut microbiota and more effectively colonize the vector.
