The evolution of the avian tail is one of the most important transitions in the history of birds, as it is the key to understanding the origin of the modern avian bauplan. However, the study of the early history of the tail is hindered by the lack of knowledge of the diversity of early pygostylians. Here, we report the discovery of a new basal member of the short-tailed bird group, Jinguofortis perplexus, which adds important information about the origin of the short-tailed bird group.

We show that stratospheric water vapor variations play an important role in the evolution of our climate. This comes from analysis of observations showing that stratospheric water vapor increases with tropospheric temperature, implying the existence of a stratospheric water vapor feedback. We estimate the strength of this feedback in a chemistry–climate model to be +0.3 W/(m2⋅K), which would be a significant contributor to the overall climate sensitivity. One-third of this feedback comes from increases in water vapor entering the stratosphere through the tropical tropopause layer, with the rest coming from increases in water vapor entering through the extratropical tropopause.

Vertebrates have a variety of colors, from red to blue, and many of them have the ability to change color. This ability is important for camouflage, communication, and other functions. In this study, we show that the ability to change color has evolved multiple times during the evolution of vertebrates. We also describe a new function for a member of the serpin superfamily, the largest and most diverse group of protease inhibitors.

Breast cancer is the most common cancer in women worldwide. The ability of breast cancer cells to form cancer stem cells (CSCs) is a major obstacle to treatment. In this study, we show that hypoxia induces the expression of ALKBH5, an m6A demethylase, which in turn increases the expression of NANOG, a gene that encodes a pluripotency factor. NANOG expression is enriched in CSCs, and ALKBH5 overexpression increases the percentage of CSCs. Thus, ALKBH5 is a potential therapeutic target for the treatment of breast cancer.

The Bible was the first book to be printed, and the first pocket Bible was produced in the 13th century. The source of the parchment used to make these Bibles has been a long-standing controversy. This study shows that the source of the parchment was not the use of fetal calves or sheep, as has been suggested, but instead reflects the availability of hides of several species of animal.

The Permian-Triassic extinction was the most severe loss of marine and terrestrial biota in the last 542 My. The age model for this event is critical for understanding its cause and the controls on extinction/recovery dynamics. We present a precise age model for the extinction and recovery based on U-Pb dates from five volcanic ash beds in China. The extinction occurred between 251.941 ± 0.037 and 251.880 ± 0.031 Mya, an interval of 60 ± 48 ka. Onset of a major reorganization of the carbon cycle immediately precedes the initiation of extinction and is punctuated by a sharp (3‰), short-lived negative spike in the isotopic composition of carbonate carbon. Carbon cycle volatility persists for ∼500 ka before a return to near preextinction values. Decamillenial to millennial level resolution of the mass extinction and its aftermath will permit a refined evaluation of the relative roles of rate-dependent processes contributing to the extinction, allowing insight into postextinction ecosystem expansion, and establish an accurate time point for evaluating the plausibility of trigger and kill mechanisms

Retinoic acid-related orphan receptor α (RORα) is a transcription factor that plays important roles in various biological processes, such as cancer, metabolism, and circadian rhythm. However, the function of RORα in the intestinal epithelium is not well understood. Here, we report that RORα is crucial for maintaining intestinal homeostasis by attenuating nuclear factor κB (NF-κB) transcriptional activity. We also demonstrate that RORα/HDAC3-mediated attenuation of NF-κB signaling controls the balance of inflammatory responses, and therapeutic strategies targeting this epigenetic regulation could be beneficial to the treatment of chronic inflammatory diseases, including inflammatory bowel disease (IBD). Our study provides insights into the function of RORα in the intestinal epithelium and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for IBD. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The spike glycoprotein of SARS-CoV-2 is the primary target for the development of vaccines and therapeutics. We have determined the structure of the SARS-CoV-2 spike in complex with the receptor ACE2, and we have compared the structure of the spike in the presence and absence of the D614G mutation. We find that the D614G mutation leads to a more open conformation of the spike, which may facilitate binding to the receptor. This work provides a structural basis for the increased infectivity of the D614G mutant virus. (Less)

We consider repeated games with tail-measurable payoffs, i.e., when the payoffs depend only on what happens in the long run. We show that every repeated game with tail-measurable payoffs admits an ε-equilibrium, for every ε>0, provided that the set of players is finite or countably infinite and the action sets are finite. The proof relies on techniques from stochastic games and from alternating-move games with Borel-measurable payoffs.

COVID-19 has resulted in a staggering death toll in the United States. We estimate that, in the absence of the pandemic, life expectancy at birth would have been 78.65 y in 2020, and at age 65 y, 83.05 y. The Black and Latino populations are estimated to experience declines in life expectancy at birth of 2.10 and 3.05 y, respectively, both of which are several times the 0.68-y reduction for Whites. Latinos, who have consistently experienced lower mortality than Whites, would see their more than 3-y survival advantage reduced to less than 1 y. These projections imply an increase of nearly 40% in the Black−White life expectancy gap, from 3.6 y to over 5 y.

The chemical properties of atoms are the basis of chemistry and are of fundamental importance in many fields of science. In this paper, we show that the chemical properties of atoms can be modified under pressure, and we propose a new way to describe these properties.

We show that human ignitions and fire suppression have been a major driver of changes in fire activity over the last century. However, we also show that these have had the effect of reducing the rate of warming, and that this effect is likely to continue in the future. This is important because of the potential for climate change to exacerbate fire activity, and the need to understand the role of human activities in mitigating this.

The mutualism between animals and their symbiotic microbes is one of the most successful and widespread forms of life on Earth. The symbionts provide essential nutrients to their hosts, while the hosts provide a suitable environment for the microbes to thrive. In this study, we show that the delivery of a single glycan, chitin, is critical for the stability of the mutualism between the squid Euprymna scolopes and its bioluminescent symbiont, Vibrio fischeri. We also show that the glycan is provided and metabolized only at night, when the squid is active and the symbiont is producing light. This study provides a new perspective on the regulation of symbiosis, and suggests that the provision of nutrients may be a common mechanism for the control of the activities of microbial communities in the body. (Less)

We introduce a method to identify latent patterns in text data. We focus on the problem of identifying topics in text, and we show how to represent documents as topic sequences. We use a generative model to infer the topic that generated a sequence of words. We illustrate our method with a prominent example of underutilized text: the US National Violent Death Reporting System (NVDRS). We identify 225 latent topics in the narratives (e.g., preparation for death and physical aggression); many of these topics are not captured by existing structured variables. We then compare the gender bias of topics to their prevalence in narratives of female versus male victims. Our method offers a flexible and broadly applicable approach to model topics in text data. It can be applied to many domains, and it can be extended to other types of data.

The second plague pandemic, which started with the arrival of Yersinia pestis in Europe in the 14th century, lasted for four centuries. This study shows that the introduction of the plague bacterium into Europe was not a one-time event, but rather the result of repeated introductions, each of which was preceded by a climate-driven rodent dispersal.

Asteroids are a major component of the marine food web and are important in the recycling of nutrients. They are also a valuable resource for the fishing industry and for the aquarium trade. The sea-star wasting disease (SSWD) is a devastating disease that has recently spread along the Pacific Coast of the United States. We show that the disease is caused by a virus and that it is spreading through the population. This is the first report of a disease agent causing mass mortality of asteroids.

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is the most common form of leukemia and is associated with a poor survival rate. There is an urgent need for novel and more efficient therapies, ideally targeting AML stem cells that are essential for maintaining the disease. We show here that monoclonal antibodies targeting the IL1RAP (IL1R3) receptor have strong antileukemic effects in xenograft models of human AML. We demonstrate that effector-cell–mediated killing is essential for the observed therapeutic effects and that natural killer cells constitute a critical human effector cell type. Because IL-1 signaling is important for the growth of AML cells, we generated an IL1RAP-targeting antibody capable of blocking IL-1 signaling and show that this antibody suppresses the proliferation of primary human AML cells. Hence, IL1RAP can be efficiently targeted with an anti-IL1RAP antibody capable of both achieving antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity and blocking of IL-1 signaling as modes of action. Collectively, these results provide important evidence in support of IL1RAP as a target for antibody-based treatment of AML. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Madagascar is a unique island in terms of its biodiversity and its human history. The island is located ∼400 km from the east coast of Africa, but its human history is very different from that of the rest of Africa. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across Madagascar, and we found that the island has been settled by a mixture of people from Africa and Asia, with a recent settlement of Madagascar from Africa. However, the distribution of African and Asian ancestry across the island reveals that the settlement was not homogeneous, suggesting that the settlement was not a single event but rather happened in several independent waves. In addition, we found that a few centuries are sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. This study provides a better understanding of the human history of Madagascar. It also provides a reference for the human history of other islands in the Indian Ocean. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Bacteria have evolved small RNAs (sRNAs) to regulate numerous biological processes and stress responses. While sRNAs generally are considered to be “noncoding,” a few have been found to also encode a small protein. Here we describe one such dual-function RNA that modulates carbon utilization in Escherichia coli. The 164-nucleotide RNA was previously shown to encode a 28-amino acid protein (denoted AzuC). We discovered the membrane-associated AzuC protein interacts with GlpD, the aerobic glycerol-3-phosphate dehydrogenase, and increases dehydrogenase activity. Overexpression of the RNA encoding AzuC results in a growth defect in glycerol and galactose medium. The defect in galactose medium was still observed for a stop codon mutant derivative, suggesting a second role for the RNA. Consistent with this observation, we found that cadA and galE are repressed by base pairing with the RNA. Interestingly, AzuC translation interferes with the observed repression of cadA and galE by the RNA and base pairing interferes with AzuC translation, demonstrating that the translation and base-pairing functions compete. The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our algorithm can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Crop experts are the eyes and ears of farmers, and their assessments are a key source of information for agricultural decision-making. However, the information provided by crop experts is often qualitative and subjective, and is not easily integrated into quantitative models. We show that the US Department of Agriculture’s Crop Progress and Condition survey, which is based on the assessments of thousands of crop experts, can be transformed into a continuous, probabilistic variable that is better suited to quantitative analysis. We also show that the survey exhibits long-term stability and can be used to monitor crop status and provide earlier and more precise predictions of crop yields than official USDA forecasts released midseason. Our work demonstrates the potential of leveraging the vast network of “people as sensors” to improve the accuracy and timeliness of agricultural monitoring and forecasting.

Language processing involves the ability to integrate information over short periods of time. This ability is thought to be supported by sustained, elevated neural activity. However, other work has argued that short-term synaptic facilitation can serve as a substrate of memory. Here we propose a mechanism that combines the two. We show that the dynamics of single neuron responses are dependent on experience, and that these adaptive changes in excitability provide memory on timescales ranging from milliseconds to seconds. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

Soil respiration is a major component of the global carbon cycle, and its response to climate change is of great interest to the scientific community and the general public. However, the majority of studies have been conducted at a single site, and the results have been inconsistent. Here, we present the results of a global synthesis of soil respiration, temperature, and moisture measurements, which provide evidence that soil respiration is not increasing in response to climate change in many biomes. Moreover, we show that soil respiration is not increasing in response to climate change in many biomes, and that the response is not consistent across all temperatures. These results highlight the need for further research to understand the complex response of soil respiration to climate change.

The evolution of the plastid genome is a key example of the interplay between natural selection and the constraints imposed by the genome itself. We show that the transition from autotrophy to a parasitic lifestyle, which is a hallmark of the evolution of the plant kingdom, is linked to a relaxation of selection on the plastid genome. Our results suggest that the transition to parasitism relaxes functional constraints on the plastid genome in a stepwise manner.

The 2015–2017 Cape Town drought was a stark reminder of the vulnerability of cities to climate change. We show that anthropogenic climate change increased the likelihood of the 2015–2017 rainfall deficit by a factor of five to six. The probability of such an event will increase from 0.7 to 25% by the year 2100 under an intermediate-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 2-4.5) and to 80% under a high-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 5-8.5). These results highlight the strong sensitivity of the drought risk in SSA to future anthropogenic emissions. This work is a timely reminder of the need to reduce greenhouse gas emissions to avoid the most severe impacts of climate change. (Abridged)

The discovery of quasicrystals in the aftermath of the first nuclear test, the “Trinity test,” has been hailed as a milestone in the history of materials science. Here, we report the discovery of a hitherto unknown composition of icosahedral quasicrystal in the red trinitite, the oldest known anthropogenic quasicrystal. The discovery of this material, which was created in the aftermath of a nuclear explosion, has implications for the study of the history of quasicrystals and for the search for extraterrestrial materials.

Photosynthesis is the most important process on Earth, and the light-harvesting pigments are the most important molecules involved in this process. The biosynthesis of these pigments is among the most productive biological pathways on Earth. The formation of the isocyclic fifth ring, the key reaction in the biosynthesis of (bacterio)chlorophylls, has remained enigmatic for more than 60 y. This reaction is catalyzed by two unrelated cyclase enzymes using different chemistries. The majority of anoxygenic phototrophic bacteria use BchE, an O2-sensitive [4Fe-4S] cluster protein, whereas plants, cyanobacteria, and some phototrophic bacteria possess an O2-dependent enzyme, the major catalytic component of which is a diiron protein, AcsF. Plant and cyanobacterial mutants in ycf54 display impaired function of the O2-dependent enzyme, accumulating the reaction substrate. Swapping cyclases between cyanobacteria and purple phototrophic bacteria reveals three classes of the O2-dependent enzyme. Neuroinflammation is a hallmark of multiple sclerosis (MS) and is associated with the development and progression of the disease. Neuroinflammation is also known to be associated with other neurodegenerative diseases. Apoptosis signal-regulating kinase 1 (ASK1) is a mitogen-activated protein kinase kinase kinase that has been implicated in neuroinflammation, but its precise cellular and molecular mechanisms remain unknown. In this study, we found that ASK1 in microglia/macrophages plays a major role in generating and maintaining disease, and ASK1 in astrocytes plays a greater proinflammatory role in the later stage of EAE. Our findings suggest that ASK1 in glial cells may be a promising therapeutic target for reducing neuroinflammation. This study also provides a better understanding of the pathophysiology of EAE and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for MS. (PsycINFO Database Record

California is currently in the midst of a record-setting drought. The drought began in 2012 and now includes the lowest calendar-year and 12-mo precipitation, the highest annual temperature, and the most extreme drought indicators on record. The extremely warm and dry conditions have led to acute water shortages, groundwater overdraft, critically low streamflow, and enhanced wildfire risk. We show that the probability of co-occurring warm and dry conditions has increased in recent decades, and that this increase is very likely due to human activities.

Autism is a complex neurodevelopmental disorder with a high heritability and a complicated etiology. Therefore, it has been challenging to identify the causal paths that lead to the core autistic symptoms such as social deficit, repetitive behaviors, and behavioral inflexibility. In this study, we used a reversal-learning task to measure behavioral flexibility in Drosophila and determined the effects of loss-of-function mutations in multiple autism-risk gene homologs in flies. We found that mutations of five autism-risk genes with diversified molecular functions all led to a similar phenotype of behavioral inflexibility indicated by impaired reversal-learning. These reversal-learning defects resulted from the inability to forget or rather, rather, to activate Rac1 (Ras-related C3 botulinum toxin substrate 1)-dependent forgetting. Thus, behavior-evoked activation of Rac1-dependent forgetting has a converging function for autism-risk genes. This study provides a mechanistic understanding of the behavioral inflexibility in autism and suggests a potential therapeutic target. This study also provides a framework for the identification of the causal paths that lead to the core autistic symptoms. (Abridged)

This work is the most comprehensive cross-national demonstration of negativity biases to date. It also highlights individual-level variation in responsiveness to news content. The results help account for the tendency for audience-seeking news around the world to be predominantly negative, and suggest that there may be reason to reconsider the conventional journalistic wisdom that “if it bleeds, it leads.”

The store-operated Ca2+ (Ca2+) (SO(2)) channel is a key regulator of cellular functions, including gene expression, cell growth and differentiation, and Ca2+ homeostasis. Loss-of-function mutations in the store-operated Ca2+ entry (SO(2)) channel pore-forming protein ORAI1 or the Ca2+ sensing protein stromal interaction molecule 1 (STIM1) result in severe immune dysfunction and nonprogressive myopathy. Here, we identify gain-of-function mutations in the cytoplasmic domain of STIM1 and in the pore-forming protein of the store (ORA) that cause congenital bleeding and myopathy, and suggest new therapies for patients with Stormorken syndrome and related conditions. These data expand our understanding of the phenotypic spectrum of dysregulated SO(2) channel signaling, advance our knowledge of the molecular function of the SO(2) channel, and suggest new therapies aiming at attenuating store-operated Ca2+ entry in the treatment of patients with Stormorken syndrome and related pathologic conditions. (Less)

The spread of protein aggregates is a key feature of many neurodegenerative diseases, including Huntington’s disease. Here we show that the spread of aggregates in a Drosophila model of Huntington’s disease is dependent on endocytosis and that this process is important for the spread of disease. We also show that the spread of aggregates is non–cell-autonomous and that the release of aggregates from the cell is important for the spread of disease. These findings have implications for the development of therapeutic strategies for neurodegenerative diseases.

Bats are increasingly recognized as potential reservoirs of many viruses that cause zoonotic disease outbreaks. However, the factors that contribute to virus spillover from bats are largely unknown. Here, we identified and characterized a protein that is highly concentrated in the submandibular salivary gland of the bat, Myotis pilosus. This protein, which we named MTX (for immunosuppressant), potently inhibits the antiviral immune response of the host and facilitates viral infection. This study provides deeper insight into immunologically privileged sites for microbial community residence in bats and supports the therapeutic potential of targeting MTX-LTA4H. This work also provides a deeper understanding of the factors that contribute to virus spillover from bats. (PsycINFO Database Record

The enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT) is a key regulator of the one-carbon pool, which is essential for cell growth. We report the discovery of a small-molecule dual inhibitor of SHMT1 and SHMT2, which is effective in cancer cell lines and xenograft tumors. We also report the discovery of a small-molecule inhibitor of SHMT2, which is effective in cancer cell lines and xenograft tumors, but is ineffective in a B-cell lymphoma cell line. This latter finding is rooted in defective glycine import, which is a targetable metabolic deficiency of B-cell lymphoma. These studies provide a foundation for the development of SHMT inhibitors as a cancer therapy. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a heterogeneous disease with a variety of genetic mutations in proteins that are highly aggregation-prone. These proteins form characteristic intracellular inclusion bodies that are present in all forms of the disease. Here, we show that the proteins that form inclusions in the brain and spinal cord are not merely a subset of the native interaction partners of these three proteins, which are themselves supersaturated. Rather, we observe that they have an average supersaturation even greater than the average supersaturation of the native interaction partners in motor neurons, but not when scores are generated from an average of other human tissues. These results suggest that inclusion bodies in various forms of ALS result from a set of proteins that are metastable in motor neurons, and thus prone to aggregation upon a disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in this specific setting. This study provides a new perspective on the pathogenesis of ALS and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies. (Less)

We present a 2D photonic crystal system for interacting with cold cesium (Cs) atoms. The band structures of the 2D photonic crystals are predicted to produce unconventional atom–light interaction behaviors, including anisotropic emission, suppressed spontaneous decay, and photon-mediated atom–atom interactions controlled by the position of the atomic array relative to the photonic crystal. An optical conveyor technique is presented for continuously loading atoms into the desired trapping positions with optimal coupling to the photonic crystal. The device configuration also enables application of optical tweezers for controlled placement of atoms. Devices can be fabricated reliably from a 200-nm silicon nitride device layer using a lithography-based process, producing predicted optical properties in transmission and reflection measurements. These 2D photonic crystal devices can be readily deployed to experiments for many-body physics with neutral atoms and engineering of exotic quantum matter.

The origin of the flowering plants is one of the most important events in the history of life. The study of the early diversification of the flowering plants is, however, hampered by a lack of knowledge of the earliest fossils. The study of Montsechia, a fossil from the early Cretaceous, opens the possibility that aquatic plants were common at an early stage of angiosperm evolution and that aquatic habitats may have played a major role in the diversification of some early angiosperm lineages.

The study of ancient viruses is hampered by the lack of ancient viral sequences. Here we present 10 ancient viral genomes, which are ∼0.5 to ∼6.9 kya old. We find that the most recent common ancestor of all B19V is placed ∼12.6 kya, and we are able to date the recombination event between genotypes 1 and 3 that formed genotype 2 to ∼5.0–6.8 kya. This study emphasizes the importance of ancient viral sequences for our understanding of virus evolution and phylogenetics. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.
Sea level is a key indicator of global climate change. We show that the rate of sea level rise is accelerating, and that this acceleration is consistent with the rate predicted by climate models.

Pain is a common and costly problem in America today. We show that, for those with less education, each successive birth cohort has a higher prevalence of pain at each age—a result not found for those with a bachelor’s degree. The increase seen across birth cohorts cannot be explained by changes in occupation or levels of obesity for the less educated, but fits a more general pattern seen in the ongoing erosion of working-class life for those born after 1950. If these patterns continue, pain prevalence will continue to increase for all adults; importantly, tomorrow’s elderly will be sicker than today’s elderly, with potentially serious implications for healthcare.

The study of enzyme mechanisms is a central goal of structural biology. Here, we use NMR-assisted crystallography to provide a detailed picture of the structure and dynamics of a key enzyme intermediate. This study demonstrates the power of NMR-assisted crystallography to provide a chemically detailed, three-dimensional picture of structure and reactivity, and to elucidate the reaction pathway back to the preceding transition state. This approach is expected to be broadly applicable to a wide range of enzyme mechanisms.

Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) is a severe respiratory disease caused by a coronavirus. There is no specific antiviral treatment available, and the disease has a high case fatality rate. Here, we show that remdesivir, an antiviral drug that is currently in clinical use for the treatment of Ebola, effectively inhibits MERS-CoV replication in vitro and in vivo. In addition, we show that remdesivir is highly effective in preventing and treating MERS-CoV infection in a nonhuman primate model. These data support the use of remdesivir in a clinical trial for the treatment of MERS, and also suggest that remdesivir may be effective against other coronaviruses, including the currently emerging novel coronavirus 2019-nCoV. This may provide a rapid treatment option for the treatment of coronavirus infections in the future. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The mutualism between symbiotic microbes and their animal hosts is one of the most common and successful forms of life on Earth. The symbionts of these associations are often associated with the animal’s epithelium, where they can influence the host’s physiology and behavior. Here, we show that the provision of a single glycan, chitin, can regulate the activity of the epithelium-associated symbionts, and thus the health of the host.

This study shows that it is possible to reduce suspension rates in schools, and that this can be achieved through a scalable, evidence-based intervention. The study also shows that the quality of teacher–student relationships is a powerful predictor of whether students are suspended. This work has implications for the future of American schools.

DNA alkylation is a major source of DNA damage that can lead to transcriptional mutagenesis. However, the molecular mechanisms of DNA alkylation-induced transcriptional stalling and mutagenesis remain unknown. In this study, we systematically investigated how RNA polymerase II (pol II) recognizes and bypasses regioisomeric O2-, N3-, and O4-ethylthymidine (O2-, N3-, and O4-EtdT) lesions. We found that the O2-EtdT lesion is error-prone, while the N3-EtdT lesion is error-free. The O4-EtdT lesion is a mixed-type lesion, which can be bypassed by both error-prone and error-free routes. We also identified a minor-groove–sensing motif from pol II (termed Pro-Gate loop), which is involved in modulating the translocation of minor-groove alkylated DNA template after nucleotide incorporation opposite the lesion. These findings provide important mechanistic insights into transcriptional stalling, lesion bypass, and mutagenesis of alkylated DNA lesions. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a zoonotic pathogen that causes severe respiratory disease. Virions require spike (S) glycoproteins for binding to cell receptors and for catalyzing virus–cell membrane fusion. We show that the MERS S protein is cleaved sequentially during its secretion through the exocytic organelles of virus-producing cells, and then after binding to target-cell receptors. These sequential cleavages are required for MERS-CoV infection of human lung-derived cells, but not of other cell types. The requirement for sequential proteolysis is significant for MERS-CoV virulence, because it expands virus tropism to cell types that are relevant to lung infection.

The food system is a major driver of environmental degradation and a leading cause of biodiversity loss. The food choices of the population have the potential to make a significant contribution to reducing this impact. However, the food system is also a major driver of obesity and other health problems. This study shows that it is possible to make a positive contribution to both of these challenges by simply changing the proportion of vegetarian meals offered in a catering service. This approach could be easily implemented in a wide range of settings and would have the potential to make a significant contribution to reducing the environmental impact of the food system and improving population health.

The cell surface proteome is the interface for the cell with the extracellular space. We have developed a method to analyze the surfaceome of a cell, and have applied it to characterize the surfaceome of a panel of breast cancer cells expressing oncogenes. We find that each oncogene has a different surfaceome, but that the functions of the proteins are harmonized by common biological themes. We also find that the surfaceome is remodeled in a cell autologous fashion by oncogenes, and that this is accompanied by changes to the glycoproteome. These studies provide a systems-level view of how oncogenes remodel the surfaceome and the glycoproteome in a cell autologous fashion, and suggest possible surface targets, and combinations thereof, for drug and biomarker discovery. This work is expected to be of interest to the broader scientific community, and to be of use to the public through the development of new biomarkers and therapeutics.

The COVID-19 pandemic has led to a surge in interest in vote-by-mail programs, which allow voters to cast their ballots by mail. This paper provides a comprehensive analysis of the effects of vote-by-mail on the 2020 election. We use a difference-in-differences design to estimate the effects of vote-by-mail on turnout, vote share, and the share of the vote won by each party. We find that vote-by-mail does not appear to affect either party’s share of turnout or vote share, and that it modestly increases overall turnout. These findings support the conventional wisdom of election administration experts and contradict many popular claims in the media. We hope that this paper will help to inform the public debate about the merits of vote-by-mail.

The COVID-19 pandemic has had a devastating impact on the global community. The molecular basis for the severity and rapid spread of the disease is largely unknown. In this work, we report the crystal structure of SARS-CoV-2 ORF8, which is a rapidly evolving accessory protein that has been proposed to interfere with immune responses. The structure reveals a unique dimerization interface that is specific to SARS-CoV-2, which may be important for immune evasion. This work provides insight into the molecular basis of the COVID-19 pandemic and may lead to the development of new therapeutics. (Less)

Hypoxia is a common condition in the human body, and it is also a major factor in the pathogenesis of cerebral edema. However, the mechanisms of cerebral edema induced by hypoxia are not fully understood. Here we show that hypobaric hypoxia induces cerebral edema in rats and neuronal apoptosis in the cortex. We also show that this hypoxia-induced cerebral edema is mediated by the release of corticotrophin releasing factor (CRF) from the hypothalamus, which acts on the CRF receptor type 1 (CRFR1) in cortical astrocytes to trigger the expression of aquaporin-4 (AQP4) and endothelin-1 (ET-1), leading to an increase in water influx into astrocytes and cerebral edema. These findings provide insights into the mechanisms of cerebral edema induced by hypobaric hypoxia. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The problem of selective inference is the challenge of assessing the strength of associations in a dataset that has been “cherry picked” for the strongest associations. This is a problem that is becoming more important in the era of big data and complex statistical modeling. We describe some recent new developments in selective inference and illustrate their use in forward stepwise regression, the lasso, and principal components analysis.

The generation of endothelial cells (ECs) is a critical step in the development of vascular networks. In this study, we demonstrate that the transcription factor Ets variant 2 (ETV2) can directly induce the formation of functional vascular ECs (ETVECs) from human fibroblasts. The ETV2-induced ECs exhibit EC characteristics in vitro and form mature functional vasculature in Matrigel plugs transplanted in NOD SCID mice. Furthermore, ETVECs significantly improve blood flow recovery in a hind limb ischemic model using BALB/c-nu mice. Our study indicates that the creation of ETVECs provides further understanding of human EC development induced by ETV2. This approach may be useful for the generation of ECs for therapeutic purposes. (Abridged)

The discovery of ALKAL1 and ALKAL2 (also named “augmentor-β” and “augmentor-α” or “FAM150A” and “FAM150B,” respectively) as ligands of anaplastic lymphoma kinase (Alk) and leucocyte tyrosine kinase (Ltk) has opened up a new field of research in the field of RTKs. In this study, we show that these ligands play an important role in zebrafish pigment development. We also demonstrate that the two ligands encoded by the human genome are essential for iridophore differentiation in zebrafish. These experiments establish a physiological link between augmentor ligands and Ltk and demonstrate that particular augmentors activate Ltk in a tissue-specific context to induce iridophore differentiation from neural crest-derived cells and pigment progenitor cells. This study provides a new perspective on the role of RTKs in development and disease. It also opens up the possibility of using zebrafish as a model to study the role of augmentor ligands in human diseases.

Type 2 diabetes (T2D) is a complex metabolic disorder that is associated with insulin resistance and β-cell dysfunction. Although the role of STING in T2D has been reported, its function in β-cells remains unknown. Herein, we found that STING is decreased in islets of db/db mice and patients with T2D, suggesting a possible role of STING in β-cell dysfunction. Indeed, STING deficiency in β-cells impaired glucose-stimulated insulin secretion, leading to T2D. These findings establish pathophysiological significance of fine-tuned STING within β-cells and insulin target tissues for maintaining glucose homeostasis. This study also provides a potential therapeutic target for the treatment of T2D. (PsycINFO Database Record

Influenza A viruses are the most important cause of human and animal morbidity and mortality. They are divided into two groups, based on their genome organization. The group that causes annual epidemics is composed of segmented genomes, whereas the group that causes occasional severe pandemics has a single-stranded genome. The latter group is more difficult to study, as it is more difficult to manipulate and less conserved among different strains. Here, we identified a mechanism that is used by the single-stranded genome of an avian influenza A virus to promote the selective packaging of the viral genome into virions. This mechanism is not widely conserved among influenza A viruses, suggesting that it might be important for the maintenance of genetic stability. This mechanism might also be important for the maintenance of genetic stability in the group of segmented viruses. This study provides insights into the molecular mechanisms that are used by viruses to package their genomes into virions. (Less)

Atherosclerosis is the leading cause of death worldwide. The development of atherosclerotic lesions is a complex process that involves a series of events, including the activation of proatherosclerotic phenotypes of vascular cells. The objective of this study is to investigate the functional role of Yes-associated protein (YAP)/transcriptional coactivator with PDZ-binding motif (TAZ) in the flow regulation of atheroprone endothelial phenotypes and the consequential development of atherosclerotic lesions. Our results demonstrate a critical role of the activation of YAP/TAZ by disturbed flow in promoting atheroprone phenotypes and atherosclerotic lesion development. Therefore, inhibition of YAP/TAZ activation is a promising athero-protective therapeutic strategy. This study provides a mechanistic understanding of the role of YAP/TAZ in the development of atherosclerotic lesions and may lead to the development of a therapeutic strategy for the prevention and treatment of atherosclerosis. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Wildfire is a natural process that has been an integral part of the Earth system for millennia. However, in the United States, the economic and ecological costs of wildfire have risen substantially in recent decades. Although climate change has likely enabled a portion of the increase in wildfire activity, the direct role of people in increasing wildfire activity has been largely overlooked. We show that the spatial and seasonal extent of human-caused wildfires has expanded dramatically in recent decades, and that this expansion has disproportionately occurred in areas where people live and work. Actions to reduce fire risk and associated hazards should focus on reducing the expansion of human-caused wildfires.

We use computer vision methods to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We find that the physical appearances of neighborhoods are correlated with the economic and demographic characteristics of their residents. These results are consistent with three classical theories of urban change: the “human capital” theory, the “tipping” theory, and the “invasion” theory. Our results suggest that the physical appearances of neighborhoods are important to the economic and social well-being of their residents. They also suggest that the physical appearances of neighborhoods can be used to understand the dynamics of urban change.

Natural repellents are a promising alternative to chemical pesticides, but their molecular targets in arthropods remain to be elucidated. Here, we report the identification of a scorpion TRP channel as a receptor of plant-derived natural repellents, which mediates avoidance behavior. This study provides a molecular target of natural repellents in arthropods, and should help the rational design of insect control strategy and in conserving biodiversity. It should also help the understanding of the evolution of the arthropod–plant interaction. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The recent outbreak of Zika virus (ZIKV) has been associated with severe fetal abnormalities and neurological complications. The mechanisms of disease are not fully understood, but the role of the immune system in the pathogenesis of ZIKV is still unclear. Here we present a mathematical analysis of the within-host dynamics of ZIKV in a nonhuman primate model, allowing for characterization of the growth and clearance of ZIKV within individual macaques. We show that the antiviral treatment favipiravir can reduce the time to undetectable plasma viral load by ∼2 d, whereas treatment given 2 d postinfection is mostly ineffective in accelerating plasma viral load loss. These results provide insights into the mechanisms of disease and the potential of antiviral treatment for ZIKV infection. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Coral bleaching is a well-known phenomenon that is often used as a proxy for the health of coral reefs. However, the underlying mechanisms are still poorly understood. Here, we show that the breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis is driven by altered nutrient cycling and energy availability. This provides a missing link in our understanding of the environmental drivers of bleaching and may ultimately help uncover fundamental processes underpinning the functioning of endosymbioses in general. Our results have implications for our understanding of the stability of the coral holobiont in light of its metabolic interactions. This may help to explain the stability of the coral–algal symbiosis in some species and may help to predict the outcome of future environmental changes. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The intestinal epithelium is a barrier that protects the organism from the environment and regulates the absorption of nutrients, the mounting of immune responses, and the prevention of systemic infections. In this study, we show that the loss of BMP signaling in the intestinal epithelium leads to the development of intestinal tumors, which in turn, trigger a regenerative response in the microbiome and stimulate tumor growth. Our results identify a JNK-dependent feedback amplification loop between intestinal tumors and the microbiome, and they highlight the importance of controlling the activity level of JNK signaling to maintain epithelial barrier function and host–microbe homeostasis. These findings have implications for the development of therapeutic strategies to control tumor growth and restore host–microbe homeostasis. They also provide insights into the mechanisms that regulate the interaction between the intestinal epithelium and the microbiome. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Breast cancer is the most common cancer in women worldwide. Although the majority of breast cancers are hormone receptor-positive, a small percentage of tumors are hormone receptor-negative. These tumors are more likely to be resistant to endocrine therapy, and therefore, there is a need for new therapeutic strategies. Here we show that the orphan receptor ROR1 is expressed in a small percentage of breast cancers, and that its expression is increased following treatment with chemotherapy. We also show that targeting ROR1 with an anti-ROR1 monoclonal antibody or by inhibiting the expression of ROR1 in breast cancer cells can inhibit the growth of breast cancer patient-derived xenografts in mice. These results suggest that targeting ROR1 may be a promising strategy for the treatment of breast cancer. (Less)

The timing of the start of accelerated deglaciation is still debated. Here we show that a series of halogen-rich volcanic eruptions, which occurred exactly at the start of accelerated deglaciation, led to stratospheric ozone depletion and a change in Southern Hemisphere climate.

Freshwater fisheries are a critical source of food, recreation, and commerce for hundreds of millions of people worldwide. However, they are often overlooked in conservation and management efforts. We present a global map of riverine fisheries, which reveals that 90% of the world’s catch comes from river basins with above-average stress levels. We also show that freshwater fisheries provide the equivalent of all dietary animal protein for 158 million people, many of whom are poor and undernourished. Our analysis highlights the importance of rivers and lakes in providing locally sourced, low-cost protein, but also the need to protect these ecosystems from the impacts of intensive fishing. Our data can be used to inform conservation and management efforts to protect both biodiversity and food security. (Abridged)

The development of inherently safe energy devices is a key challenge, and aqueous Li-ion batteries draw large attention for this purpose. Due to the narrow electrochemical stable potential window of aqueous electrolytes, the energy density and the selection of negative electrode materials are significantly limited. For achieving durable and high-energy aqueous Li-ion batteries, the development of negative electrode materials exhibiting a large capacity and low potential without triggering decomposition of water is crucial. Herein, a type of a negative electrode material is proposed for high-energy aqueous Li-ion batteries.

The ability to regenerate is a defining feature of the adult nervous system. However, the molecular mechanisms that control the ability of neurons to regenerate are poorly understood. Here, we identify a form of regeneration that is independent of the MAPK pathway, which is known to mediate regeneration in the adult mammalian CNS. This discovery has implications for our understanding of the molecular mechanisms that control regeneration in the adult nervous system.

Recombination is a key process in the generation of genetic diversity and the evolution of new traits. In this study, we describe the distribution of recombination across the genome of a flowering plant, Mimulus guttatus, and compare it to that in yeast and in mice.

The resting brain is a dynamic system, with fluctuations in the activity of many different brain regions. The analysis of these fluctuations has led to the identification of a small number of networks, which are assumed to be the main functional modules of the brain. However, the existence of these networks is still debated, and their functional relevance is not clear. Here, we show that the analysis of the resting brain can be extended to the analysis of the total brain activity, which is measured by metabolic imaging. This approach allows the identification of a dominant resting network, which is similar to the default mode network, and of a set of disease-related networks.

The 5′ cap structure is the most important modification of mRNA. It is essential for translation and stability of the mRNA. We report the existence of a second 5′ modification in yeast, the nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide (NAD+) group. We show that NAD-mRNA is found on subsets of nuclear and mitochondrial encoded mRNAs. NAD-mRNA appears to be produced cotranscriptionally because NAD-RNA is also found on pre-mRNAs, and only on mitochondrial transcripts that are not 5′ end processed. These results define an additional 5′ RNA cap structure in eukaryotes and raise the possibility that this 5′ NAD+ cap could modulate RNA stability and translation on specific subclasses of mRNAs. This discovery has implications for the regulation of gene expression in yeast and for the evolution of the 5′ cap structure in eukaryotes. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Metabolic memory is the prolonged beneficial effects of intensive vs. conventional therapy on the progression of microvascular complications in people with diabetes. We show that epigenetic DNA methylation differences at specific loci in blood are associated with glycemia for several years during the Diabetes Control and Complications Trial (DCCT) and support an epigenetic explanation for metabolic memory.

This study provides evidence that the expression of the cancer antigen, FSIP1, is associated with poor prognosis in breast cancer and that it is involved in the drug sensitivity of TNBC. Furthermore, we show that FSIP1 promotes autophagy, which in turn, leads to the inhibition of chemotherapy sensitivity. These findings may aid in the design of TNBC therapies. Alcohol dependence is a chronic and relapsing disorder that affects the brain and the gut. The present study shows that the gut barrier is altered in alcohol dependence, which is associated with the psychological symptoms of the disease. Moreover, the composition and activity of the gut microbiota are altered in alcohol dependence, suggesting that the gut microbiota is involved in the development of the gut barrier and in the behavioral symptoms of the disease. Thus, the gut microbiota seems to be a previously unidentified target in the management of alcohol dependence.

The flavor of tomato fruit is a complex mixture of volatile chemicals, many of which are nitrogenous compounds. The biosynthesis of these compounds is poorly understood, and the role of nitrogenous volatiles in tomato flavor is not known. Here we report the identification of a gene essential for the production of all the nitrogenous volatiles in tomato fruit. We also describe a pathway for the biosynthesis of these compounds, which is distinct from the known pathways for the biosynthesis of other tomato volatiles. This work provides a major advance in our understanding of the biosynthesis of tomato flavor, and will be useful in the development of improved tomato cultivars. (Less)

We show that the impacts of global warming on the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning are highly dependent on the thermal tolerance of species. We demonstrate that the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning is more sensitive to changes in temperature when species are more diverse, and that this sensitivity is driven by changes in the thermal tolerance of species. Our results highlight the importance of considering the thermal tolerance of species in the context of global warming, and suggest that the impacts of biodiversity loss on ecosystem functioning may be exacerbated by the additional impacts of environmental warming.

The medial entorhinal cortex (MEC) is a key hub in the mammalian brain, playing a role in navigation, memory, and other cognitive functions. The organization of its neurons is still poorly understood, in part because of the difficulty in studying the complex network of connections between them. Here, we used a portable two-photon microscope to image the activity of a large number of neurons in freely behaving mice, allowing us to study the organization of MEC in a natural environment. Our results suggest that the organization of MEC is more complex than previously thought. In particular, the neurons that encode the direction of the animal’s head are not only linked to the neurons that encode the shape of the environment but also to the neurons that encode the location of the environment. This study provides a new perspective on the organization of the MEC.

Flowering is a complex process that is controlled by a variety of factors, including environmental cues, such as day length. Dodder is a root- and leafless plant that parasitizes a large number of autotrophic plants. Dodder is able to synchronize its flowering with the flowering of its hosts. Here, we show that the flowering of the host is required for the flowering of the dodder. This study demonstrates that FTs can function as an important interplant flowering signal in host–dodder interactions.

Parkinson’s disease is a disorder of the nigrostriatal dopamine system. The precise nature of the pathology in this disorder is not fully understood, but it is clear that the disease is multifactorial. Here we show that the dopamine-containing neurons of the nigrostriatal system are not the only dopamine-containing neurons in the brain. We also show that the dopamine-containing neurons of the nigrostriatal system are not the only dopamine-containing neurons in the brain that are affected in Parkinson’s disease.

We are social creatures, and we seek connection with others. We have a rich set of metaphors for describing the feeling of connection, but how do we know when two people are connected? We conducted a series of experiments to show that the speed at which people respond to each other is a robust and sufficient signal of connection. This signal is used by people to evaluate the quality of their connections with others, and it is used by third-party listeners to evaluate the quality of the connections between two people.

Silicon (Si) is an essential element for plant growth and development, and its beneficial effects on plant resistance against abiotic and biotic stresses have been well documented. However, the role of Si in mediating insect herbivore defense responses has not been explored. Here, we show that Si pretreatment of rice plants increases resistance against the rice leaffolder, a major insect pest of rice, and that this effect is associated with an increase in Si deposition and Si cell expansion, as well as with an increase in jasmonate (JA) accumulation and defense responses. These results suggest that Si may promote insect herbivore defense responses by increasing the availability of Si and the accumulation of Si in the plant, and that this may be mediated by JA. This study provides insights into the potential of Si as a biocontrol agent for insect pests. (Abridged)

The role of tetrahydrobiopterin in lipid metabolism is not well understood. Here we show that tetrahydrobiopterin is essential for the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase, which is involved in the metabolism of ether lipids. We also show that tetrahydrobiopterin and alkylglycerol monooxygenase are important for the regulation of the lipidome in macrophages.

Language processing is a complex task that involves the ability to integrate information over short periods of time. Here we propose a mechanism that supports this process. Information is stored in the form of changes in the excitability of neural populations. These changes are adaptive and can be accessed directly without the need for cued retrieval. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order which makes it suitable for temporal integration in sequence processing within the language domain. We believe that this work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

The delivery of biomolecules to plants is a challenge due to the cell wall, which is absent in mammalian cells. Here, we report the delivery of siRNA to plants with DNA nanostructures, which are able to deliver siRNA across the cell wall. We show that the size, shape, compactness, stiffness, and attachment location of the DNA nanostructure are important parameters for the delivery and gene silencing efficiency. We also show that the delivery of siRNA to plants is dependent on the endogenous gene silencing pathway. Our work establishes the feasibility of DNA nanostructures for the delivery of biomolecules to plants and also details the design parameters of importance for plant cell internalization and also assesses the impact of DNA nanostructure geometry for gene silencing mechanisms. This work is expected to be useful for the delivery of biomolecules to plants in the future.

The world’s largest freshwater bodies are threatened by nutrient pollution, which is driven by nonpoint sources from surrounding watersheds. However, the role of small tributaries in delivering nutrients to coastal areas is largely unknown. We show that the 6 largest of 235 tributaries to Lake Michigan account for ∼70% of the daily nutrient loads delivered to the lake. However, small tributaries exhibit nutrient loads that are high for their size and biased toward dissolved inorganic forms. This suggests that their plumes become trapped and then overlap in the nearshore zone, increasing the potential for coastal eutrophication. Our findings reveal an underappreciated role that small streams may play in driving coastal eutrophication in large water bodies.

We study the dynamics of a simple chemical network in a thermodynamic environment that is biased toward rare combinations of chemical concentrations. We find that the long-time dynamics of such systems are biased toward states that exhibit a fine-tuned extremization of the environment. This behavior is reminiscent of the “fine-tuning problem” in cosmology, where the environment is the cosmic microwave background, and the rare combinations of chemical concentrations are the ones that extremize the environment.

This study provides a mechanistic understanding of the mechanisms underlying the effects of NMDA-receptor antibodies on the brain’s electrical activity. The study also provides a framework for understanding the effects of other types of antibodies on the brain’s electrical activity.

The Earth system is currently undergoing a period of rapid climate change, and it is important to understand how the system responded to abrupt warming in the past. Here, we present a study of an abrupt warming event that occurred during a glacial period. We show that the event was linked to a global warming and that the warming was linked to an increase in atmospheric CO2.

The Roundtable on Sustainable Palm Oil (RSPO) is the most widely used certification scheme for palm oil. We show that certification reduced deforestation in Indonesia, but that the benefits were limited by the fact that most certified areas contained little residual forest. We also show that certification had no causal impact on forest loss in peatlands or active fire detection rates. Our results suggest that certification is not a silver bullet for reducing deforestation, but that it can be an important tool in the toolbox of policies to reduce deforestation.

The exocyst complex is involved in the regulation of exocytosis, which is essential to organisms across kingdoms. However, the study of the dynamic regulation of the exocyst-related processes using mutants in genetically tractable organisms such as Arabidopsis thaliana is limited by the lethality or the severity of phenotypes. We discovered that the small molecule Endosidin2 (ES2) binds to the EXO70 (exocyst component of 70 kDa) subunit of the exocyst complex, resulting in inhibition of exocytosis and endosomal recycling in both plant and human cells and enhancement of plant vacuolar trafficking. This study provides a valuable tool in studying exocytosis regulation and a potentially new target for drugs aimed at addressing human disease. (Less)

Sex determination is a fundamental process in biology, and the genetic basis of sex determination is a major area of study. In vertebrates, sex determination is often a single locus, but in some species, multiple sex determination alleles are inherited together. In this study, we show that the genetic basis of sex determination in a cichlid fish can produce a modular system of sexual traits, and that the modular system can be modified by the acquisition of a new sex determination allele. This study provides a model for understanding the evolution of sex determination and its effects on the development of secondary sexual traits.

The retina is challenged by a variety of factors that can lead to photoreceptor cell death. One of these factors is the accumulation of vitamin A aldehyde adducts (bisretinoids) that photogenerate reactive oxygen species and photodecompose into damaging aldehyde- and dicarbonyl-bearing species. We show that the Fe chelator deferiprone (DFP) reduces the oxidation and degradation of the bisretinoid A2E in the presence of light and reduces cell death in cell-based experiments. These findings suggest that Fe levels in the retina are important in the photooxidation and photodegradation of the bisretinoid A2E, which may contribute to the loss of photoreceptor cells in retinal diseases. This work also provides a rationale for the use of DFP in the treatment of retinal diseases. (Abridged)

The evolution of specialization is one of the most important processes in ecology and evolution. However, the evolution of specialization is often considered a dead end, as it is difficult to evolve new structures and functions that are dedicated to a single prey type. Here we show that the evolution of specialization in siphonophores is not a dead end, but rather a process that has led to the evolution of new prey types. Our results help us understand the evolution of specialization and morphological evolution, and how these processes have shaped present-day food webs.

The evolution of the human hand is one of the most important and least understood aspects of human evolution. This is because of the paucity of hand fossils in the hominin fossil record between 800,000 and 1.8 My old, a time interval well documented for the emergence and subsequent proliferation of Acheulian technology. This study provides the earliest unambiguous evidence for the evolution of a key shared derived characteristic of modern human and Neandertal hand morphology and suggests that the distinctive complex of radial carpometacarpal joint features in the human hand arose early in the evolution of the genus Homo and probably in Homo erectus sensu lato.

The enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT) is a key regulator of the one-carbon pool, which is essential for cell growth. We report the discovery of a small-molecule dual inhibitor of SHMT1 and SHMT2, which is effective in cancer cell lines and xenograft tumors. We also report the discovery of a unique metabolic vulnerability of diffuse large B-cell lymphoma, which is rooted in defective glycine import. These findings have implications for the development of cancer therapeutics. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

This study shows that deforestation can have a negative impact on people’s diets and dietary vitamin A adequacy. This is important because, despite a growing body of literature that shows that having access to forests can improve people’s diets, particularly in rural areas of low- and middle-income countries, there is little consideration of the role of forests in meeting nutrition goals. This study has important implications for policy makers given that forests are largely overlooked in strategies to improve nutrition, but offer potential “win–wins” in terms of meeting nutrition goals as well as conservation and environmental goals. This study also highlights the need for more research on the role of natural landscapes in improving people’s diets and nutrition. This is particularly important in light of the growing global population and the increasing demand for food.

Modern agriculture is the most productive and efficient food production system in history, but it is also the most energy-intensive and resource-demanding. The use of farm machinery has been a key factor in the success of modern agriculture, but it has also contributed to the degradation of soil ecological functioning. We show that the use of farm machinery has led to the propagation of subsoil compaction into deeper soil layers, with potential loss of productivity. We also show that the total weight of modern harvesters is now approaching that of the largest animals that walked Earth, the sauropods, suggesting that unconstrained roaming of these prehistoric giants would have had similar adverse effects on land productivity as modern farm vehicles. This suggests that ecological strategies for reducing subsoil compaction, including fixed foraging trails, must have guided these prehistoric giants. This study highlights the need for a more stringent design of farm machinery that considers intrinsic subsoil mechanical limits. (Abridged)
